reviewText: These "co-ed" movies were fairly formulaic in regard to content: Simple stories of boy winning girl in a  senior high school/college setting with a plot device that sets up the couple for silly misunderstandings and mishaps on the path to love. Nothing more than a backdrop for lots of corny gags, one-liners, and light slapstick. They were meant as light entertainment, maybe equivalent to television sit-coms; and the studios  often used the films to test the marketability of new or upcoming talent while pairing them with established comedians/entertainers. The Dancing Co-ed is a great example of the genre with Lana Turner playing opposite  studio comedians with a cameo from swing sensation Artie Shaw and his band ( add in a few close-ups of  star drummer Buddy Rich)I bought this DVD solely to see Lana Turner as a young performer. I am not a huge Lana Turner fan, but I often like to view the early films of top stars and see what made them stand out, if anything. Well, Lana Turner surprised me not only for her really natural,  good looks( just her normal strawberry-blond self), but also for a kind of simple, open personality. She seems very comfortable in front of a camera. Her film persona would change very quickly to sultry, screen beauty, but  here she is the girl next-door . She even does a little tap dancing ( not bad at all) not to mention some silly, slapstick gags and is completely at ease.Interestingly, Miss Turner in this film  resembles Betty Grable when she did co-ed films in looks and demeanor. Grable just graduated from co-ed films at the time of Dancing Co-Eds and within a year (1940) would star in her first big musical hits. Like Grable and many film stars, there is a natural on-screen poise that distinguishes Turner. Screen charisma, whatever you want to call it, she had it.

reviewText: Lana again shows her wonderful talent of dancing, which she always love, even as a little girl, as well as a fine acting ability-all at a young age!A delightful movie for Lana!

reviewText: Lana Turner is remarkably young and fresh in this funny musical film, one of the best released in the year 1939, sometimes spoken of as the greatest single year for the movies.  If DANCING CO-ED was nothing more than a programmer, a movie destined to be sold together with an "A" picture and never considered very high-class nor prestigious, it just shows you that ironically enough, a mere trifle like this one turns out to be better than GONE WITH THE WIND, MR SMITH GOES TO WASHINGTON, WUTHERING HEIGHTS, STAGECOACH, LOVE AFFAIR, DESTRY RIDES AGAIN, THE HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME, and the other films often trotted out to prove that 1939 was the apex of the studio system.  Turner plays a young Broadway dancer who hasn't quite made it, and who gets plummeted into a large Midwestern university (called, ridiculously enough, "Midwestern") through a series of quite extensive plot machinations.  Indeed the back story of DANCING CO-ED is so tangled and crazy it sort of takes the fun away from the story of college hijinks and good times.  I can't even paraphrase it, except to say that a star team of married dancers (like Fred and Ginger, except married) are about to start the biggest picture of their careers, when a Winchell-type broadcaster reveals to a nationwide audience that the distaff half of the team (Mary Beth Hughes--blink and you'll miss her) is pregnant, throwing the movie into disarray.  The powers that be decide to embark on a nationwide hunt for her replacement, ad the hook will be that, because the movie in question is to be called Dancing Co-Ed, they will get a real co-ed to play the part.  The publicity will be enormous they figure.  Why not cast Lana as a co-ed?  I suppose nobody would believe it.  Instead she's a dancer whom the overanxious producer all but guarantees the part to, if she's game enough to enter Midwestern despite, apparently, never having gone to school past "Standard Three," whatever that is.No problem, her girlfriend Ann Rutherford will take her exams for her and get her into the school.  Rutherford is lovely here and has considerably more to do than she did in GONE WITH THE WIND, a long drawnout movie with more things on its mind than showcasing Rutherford's entrance into a nationwide dance contest, swinging and swaying solo to Artie Shaw's clarinet, a gym filled with screaming kids cheering her on.Richard Carlson plays the star reporter on the Midwestern "Porcupine," the school newspaper, and Monty Woolley is hilarious as the English poetry teacher who seems like a mean old cuss, but tolerates all sorts of co-ed shenanigans with a twinkle in his eye.  Above all the other acting talent (and every role has been filled perfectly, right down to the college dance teacher who just loves her new student to death!) shines the incandescent, dewy and supple Lana Turner, very different here than in her later, harder roles.  Here she is simply adorable, and every line reading is inventive, witty and well, darn cute is all.  She makes it look like she's a natural.  I wonder what happened later on when stardom came and she descended, or ascended, into the superb stylization we know her best from---the grand manner she seemed to love, and yet seemed so uncomfortable with.  The white turban era.  Here there's no turban in sight, and yet every frame's a winner.

reviewText: I must say that I'm very impressed with what Warner Archives is doing.  The quality is excellent as the DVD's are made from studio original reference prints.It's really great that Warners, sometimes in association with the holdings of Turner, have made the commitment to rerelease some of the gems of early Americanfilms which have been unavailable to be seen by the general public for a couple of generations.  Some of these, like Dancing Co-Ed have a limited niche marketbut will be wildly popular among film enthusiasts seeking to see and relive the pleasures of films from the Golden Age of the Old Hollywood.  Many films fromthe 1930's and 40's haven't survived or haven't been reproduced for modern electronic media because of their arguably lack of economic viability.The legendary Lana Turner led the quintessentially glamorous Hollywood life, with its numerous romances and ups and downs that are ultimately fascinatingto the celebrity fan or movie history buff.  She was recruited as a young girl by the legendary Billy Wilkerson, publisher of the Hollywood Reporter, and placed undera personal contract to Mervyn LeRoy, at Warners.  When LeRoy moved to MGM in the later 30's Lana went with him.  Dancing Co-Ed wasn't Lana's first film but it wasone of her very earliest ones.  She had made at least nine previous films by 1939 when Dancing Co-Ed was filmed at MGM.  At the time of filming, Lana met herfirst of many husbands, swing band leader Artie Shaw, who is featured in this film.  Actor Richard Carlson also is seen in a very effective role as a campus newspapereditor who takes his newspaperman's job, and Lana's character, very seriously.  The nature of Dancing Co-Ed is a slightly "screwball" light and effective musicalcomedy about a rising young movie hopeful being planted on a college campus as a studio publicity stunt that develops out-of-control complications.  The story istypical of many similar college campus stories that became popular plot material for early Hollywood films especially during the rise of the Big Band Swing Era.If you like this sort of light hearted boy gets girl type of plot and are nostalgic for the simple story lines of early Hollywood features you would probably enjoy thislight hearted outing.  If you are fascinated by the colorful life of Lana Turner, as I am, you would enjoy seeing the beautiful young Lana, near the beginning of herstudio career, in a still fresh and entertaining film. There are not many early Lana Turner films available yet on DVD, but as Warner Archives churns away at someof the contents of their deep film vaults, perhaps more of these will come to light.  I enjoyed Dancing Co-Ed and thought it was a wonderful insight intoHollywood's Golden Era.  (If you enjoy this movie, I highly recommend the newly published book on Lana Turner, which is also available on Amazon.com.  It waswritten and edited by her daughter, Cheryl Crane, and is sensational.  It's entitled: Lana: "The Memories, the Myths, the Movies"  It's gloriously illustrated and isthe probably the best book yet published detailing the life and times of Lana Turner.)
summary: Great Early Lana Turner Movie Finally Available

reviewText: I purchased this film because I really enjoy Lana Turner however,  this film left me feeling like she wasn't really in it. She didn't have her usual flair. Granted it was one of her earlier works but she just didn't have the same magic on film as she has in her other work. It was sort of like she wasn't feeling her part either. Not one of her better works so if you are buying this just for Lana, then don't waste your time or money.
summary: Not one of her better works
